channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-920] HTTP to HTTP performance problems, very low TPS
item.description:
The dev team migrating the DataPower flows started those flows with HTTP to HTTP communication.
They are reporting to me performance problems where they can't seem to have the engine running at more than 1 TPS.
It got me by surprise as I have heavily worked on HTTP to JMS and JMS to HTTP scenarios assuming HTTP to HTTP wouldn't be a problem.
I've run some very basic trials and I'm getting problems too, so it seems there is something fishy there.

This is the URI I'm using when sending from fuse the HTTP message:
"netty-http:http://localhost:8050/some/uri?requestTimeout=10000&throwExceptionOnFailure=false"

I have a netty stub delaying the call 2 seconds, and I'm sending at a rate of 5 TPS.
The stub is getting some ClosedChannelExceptions, I would assume caused by Fuse while the connection between the two is open.
Fuse is showing the following exception:

14:52:09,159 | ERROR | yClientTCPWorker | 0_handle-Exception | 134 - org.apache.camel.camel-core - 2.12.0.redhat-610054 | STACKTRACE: java.nio.channels.ClosedChannelException
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.AbstractNioWorker.cleanUpWriteBuffer(AbstractNioWorker.java:434)
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.AbstractNioWorker.close(AbstractNioWorker.java:374)
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.NioWorker.read(NioWorker.java:93)
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.AbstractNioWorker.process(AbstractNioWorker.java:109)
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.AbstractNioSelector.run(AbstractNioSelector.java:312)
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.AbstractNioWorker.run(AbstractNioWorker.java:90)
at org.jboss.netty.channel.socket.nio.NioWorker.run(NioWorker.java:178)
at org.jboss.netty.util.ThreadRenamingRunnable.run(ThreadRenamingRunnable.java:108)
at org.jboss.netty.util.internal.DeadLockProofWorker$1.run(DeadLockProofWorker.java:42)
at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.runTask(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:895)
at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:918)
at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:662)

Any chance you can check out this HTTP to HTTP issue, you should see the same for a low TPS rate.
item.summary: HTTP to HTTP performance problems, very low TPS

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
I requested a sample of their code, but due to complexities of deploying their framework, got the following response, so should provide a bit more of a means of reproducing this issue hopefully:

I'm sorry I'm not making your life very easy, the reason why I don't have a basic test is because we're using our framework which is a bit complicated and it is multi-bundle with multi camel contexts, it would be a bit hard to deploy only to test this problem.

But essentially, the steps to reproduce this problem would be very easy, it would look similar to:
from("netty-http:http://localhost:8040/in")
.to("netty-http:http://localhost:8050/out")

The above is made up, but that is what it would take to reproduce the scenario, Fuse opening an HTTP port and forwarding the message to an HTTP target.
Could you take a look at this one Willem?

Hi Nabeel,
I wrote a simple test case with the camel route like this. I used Jmeter to send the request. the TPS is around 200, if there is no thread sleep for 2 second.

               from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8901/test")
 
                    .to("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8902/test?bridgeEndpoint=true&requestTimeout=10000&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
 
 
                from("netty:http://0.0.0.0:8908/test")
 
                    .transform().simple("Bye ${body}");

If I add some thread sleep code in just like this, the TPS dropped 7 and got some error, if I changed to jetty as the back end server, the TPS is about 40.

                from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8908/test")
 
                    .process(new Processor() {
 
 
 
                        @Override
 
                        public void process(Exchange exchange) throws Exception {
 
                            Thread.sleep(2000);
 
                        }
 
                    })
 
                    .transform().simple("Bye ${body}");

As you know Netty is using few work thread to do the socket dispatch, so if the request handler takes long time to handle the request it will cause the worker thread cannot do the socket dispatch work. That could explain why you got the such low TPS and ClosedChannelExceptions.
Jetty has a thread pool to handle the application level work, so we can get a better performance in time.
For the HTTP-JMS proxy, you just turn the sync invocation into asyn invocation, so the worker thread doesn't block for a long time, so you can get a good TPS.

To resolve this issue, we may need to introduce a thread pool to handle the application level work in netty-http. And when you use Netty you should not block the work thread which dispatch socket event.

I just found an issue[1] of camel-netty-http when I did the performance test, after fix the issue I got a reasonable TPS on the netty-http route just like this.

               from("netty-http:http://localhost:8901/test")
 
                    .to("netty-http:http://localhost:8908/in?bridgeEndpoint=true&requestTimeout=10000&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                   
 
 
                // use jetty as server as it supports sending response as chunked encoding
 
                from("jetty:http://localhost:8908/in")
 
                
                    .process(new Processor() {
 
 
 
                        @Override
 
                        public void process(Exchange exchange) throws Exception {
 
                            Thread.sleep(2000);
 
                        }
 
                        
                    })
 
                   
                    .transform().simple("Bye ${body}");
 
            }
 
 

If you want to ran some test with the patch of CAMEL-6861, you can work around the issue by using the convertBodyTo(String.class) just like this.

      from("netty-http:http://localhost:8901/test")
 
                    .to("netty-http:http://localhost:8908/in?bridgeEndpoint=true&requestTimeout=10000&throwExceptionOnFailure=false")
 
                    .convertBodyTo(String.class);

[1]https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CAMEL-6861

The Netty-http Backend can be changed to use the async delayer and it can handle the normal request.

from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8908/test")
 
             .delay(2000).asyncDelayed()
 
             .transform().simple("Bye ${body}");

I also found you can change the worker count from option just like this "netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8908/test?workerCount=20"

I tried to introduce the ExecutionHandler (netty-executor) into camel-netty-http consumer, but it doesn't make much difference after ran some performance test.

Also, on the correlation question:

As far as I'm aware we don't do any correlation ourselves.
Well, I implemented it, and all I do is to delegate all the work to the Netty component, similar to one of the samples provided where the route definition looks like:

<Route>
<action a/>
<action b/>

<receipientList>
Forward to target
</receipientList>

<action c/>
<action d/>
</route>

Hi Nabeel,

I just did quick performace test with the below route to call the backend service which sends the response back after 2 second delay.
The performance is good, I can get about 10 tps if I send the requests from 20 conections.
We still need to fill in the missing part of the customer's route.

 from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8901/test")
 
                    .process(new Processor() {
 
 
 
                        @Override
 
                        public void process(Exchange exchange) throws Exception {
 
                            exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8908/test?bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                            
                        }
 
                        
                    })
 
                    .recipientList(simple("${property.target.uri}"));

BTW, I ran the test within Camel master branch.

Hi Willem,

Just a pointer to something in your last comment, they aren't using bridgeEndpoint as your are because they are modifying the headers and the URI.

Do you think the bridgeEndpoint could be really making the main difference?

Hi Nabeel,

The bridgeEndpoint option just affect the http request URI, I don't think it can made a huge difference on the performance.

Hi Nabeel,

I cannot agree the TPS assumption you just told. If you start more connection, you can get higher TPS even the back end delay is about 20 second.
such as we use 100 connection to send the request, we can still get 5 TPS even the back end delay is 20 second.

And we discussed about the backend service of the user, it doesn't have that kind of delay.

BTW, Here is the detail information about how I made the test.

I'm using httperf to send the get request to camel route and camel route redirect the request to the back end.
You can use "brew install httperf" to install it from mac OSX.

httperf --timeout=5 --client=0/1 --server=localhost --port=8901 --uri=/test --rate=10 --send-buffer=4096 --recv-buffer=16384 --num-conns=20 --num-calls=100

The Route configure is 

return new RouteBuilder() {
 
            @Override
 
            public void configure() throws Exception {
 
                final AtomicInteger count = new AtomicInteger(0);
 
                from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8901/test")
 
                    .threads(20)
 
                    .process(new Processor() {
 
 
 
                        @Override
 
                        public void process(Exchange exchange) throws Exception {
 
                            int number = count.incrementAndGet();
 
                            if ((number % 2) == 1) {
 
                                exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8908/test?bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                            } else {
 
                                exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8909/test?bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                            }
 
                            
                        }
 
                        
                    })
 
                    .recipientList(simple("${property.target.uri}"));
 
          
               from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8908/test?executor=true&workerCount=8")
 
                    .delay(2000).asyncDelayed()
 
                    .transform().simple("Bye ${body}");
 
                
                from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8909/test?executor=true&workerCount=8")
 
                    .delay(2000).asyncDelayed()
 
                    .transform().simple("Bye Bye ${body}");
 
            }
 
        };

The test result is about 10 TPS from the Request rate section.

Maximum connect burst length: 1
 
 
 
Total: connections 20 requests 2000 replies 2000 test-duration 202.189 s
 
 
 
Connection rate: 0.1 conn/s (10109.5 ms/conn, <=20 concurrent connections)
 
Connection time [ms]: min 200279.2 avg 200291.4 max 200322.1 median 0.0 stddev 11.0
 
Connection time [ms]: connect 0.2
 
Connection length [replies/conn]: 100.000
 
 
 
Request rate: 9.9 req/s (101.1 ms/req)
 
Request size [B]: 66.0
 
 
 
Reply rate [replies/s]: min 6.0 avg 9.9 max 10.2 stddev 0.6 (40 samples)
 
Reply time [ms]: response 2002.9 transfer 0.0
 
Reply size [B]: header 169.0 content 6.0 footer 0.0 (total 175.0)
 
Reply status: 1xx=0 2xx=2000 3xx=0 4xx=0 5xx=0
 
 
 
CPU time [s]: user 8.94 system 193.22 (user 4.4% system 95.6% total 100.0%)

BTW, httperf just get the segementfault if I set the connection number more than 30.

They are right, if you increase the number of connections you increase the overall TPS rate, but that wasn't really the point I was trying to make.

I'm trying to report a performance problem, and I'm trying to show it using a low TPS rate. In reality I'm targeting to reach the same performance levels that we achieved on our POC like on our scenario HTTP to JMS and JMS to HTTP, that is around 1000 TPS (depending on the environment), with 5 seconds delay on the back.

Ø So, my expectation from HTTP to HTTP is to get around 1000 TPS with 5 seconds delay on the back.

We're trying (you and me) to reproduce the problem with low TPS rate. Clearly we're getting different results at the moment. My suspicion is that your route definition and your test client manage to work well at 10tps, this could be due to the combination of factors: thread pools configuration, number of connections, the 2 seconds delay. I think if you start increasing the TPS rate (50 tps, 100tps, 200 tps, 500 tps), and set your delay to 5 seconds you will start seeing lots of problems.

Bear in mind, in my case I'm using the same Camel routes to perform JMS to HTTP, HTTP to JMS, and HTTP to HTTP.
The first two JMS to HTTP and HTTP to JMS are super fast, as we all know. And my point is that HTTP to HTTP should be as fast as the other two.

I see in your route you define a threadpool (threads(20)), this may be helping to achieve your 10tps.
Ø What would happen if you remove it? Netty is asynchronous, it should not need 20 threads to cope with 10 TPS
Ø What happens if you increase the load to high TPS rates?

You asked me to put together a sample flow, I haven't done it yet.
I can do it, but then we have to agree on not changing its definition so that we test in equal conditions.
About thread pool configurations, I defend the fact that Netty should be able to handle high loads (>100tps) with only 1 thread, as it is using non blocking IO.

Let me know how you would us to move forward from here.

Hi Willem,

Having discussed this with the customer more, the main concern highlighted above is that your flow is different then theirs in the fact that you are adding a thread pool to be able to get to the TPS number that is being discussed. And that to get 10 TPS, it would be expected that Netty would be able to handle this without the need of a thread pool, not until you get to higher TPS.

So, it would be good to get a view of what you see in terms of TPS without the thread pool as that makes a big difference regarding what the customer is trying? That way, if we can agree on a flow that works for everything, then we can focus on that as being the main test case and ensuring that the TPS seen by the customer and RH is the same and then figuring out how to resolve it if it comes out to be low.

Many thanks.

Hi Nabeel,

I just ran the performance test with the default setting of camel-netty-http just like this.
The threads DSL is just for testing, you didn't need to use that.

            public void configure() throws Exception {
 
                final AtomicInteger count = new AtomicInteger(0);
 
                from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8901/test")
 
                    .process(new Processor() {
 
 
 
                        @Override
 
                        public void process(Exchange exchange) throws Exception {
 
                            int number = count.incrementAndGet();
 
                            if ((number % 2) == 1) {
 
                                exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8908/test?bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                            } else {
 
                                exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8909/test?bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                            }
 
                            
                        }
 
                        
                    })
 
                    .recipientList(simple("${property.target.uri}"));
 
                   
                from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8908/test")
 
                    .delay(2000).asyncDelayed()
 
                    .transform().simple("Bye ${body}");
 
                
                from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8909/test")
 
                    .delay(2000).asyncDelayed()
 
                    .transform().simple("Bye Bye ${body}");
 
            }

I still get the around 10 TPS by using the httperf.

Back to the HTTP to JMS and JMS to HTTP, it just break the request/response module into two async invocation. I'm not sure if the client need to check the response message. If the client who invokes the service doesn't need to wait for the response from the back end, the performance test could get very high TPS by using a dozen of connections, as it doesn't need to wait for the response.

Willem,

Can we do one more test before I go back to the customer. He'd suggested:
" I think if you start increasing the TPS rate (50 tps, 100tps, 200 tps, 500 tps), and set your delay to 5 seconds you will start seeing lots of problems."

Could you see what kind of TPS you'll get if your delay is longer and you send more requests?
If you don't see any issues then with more load, then I'll tell him he has to provide us with a way to replicate the issue he's seeing with your code. Or that he needs to provide a sample that shows his code and why it's different then what you are doing.

Many thanks

Hi Nabeel

I will run some test to increase the pressure on the route.
BTW, I'm running the test within Camel trunk, I just want to ask if the customer tried the latest Fuse 6.1 SNAPSHOT, as we fix some of camel-netty-http related issue recently.

Regards,

Willem

Willem, the last test they ran was on build 137. Should they try anything more recent then that?

I can have them do that while you do a slightly higher pressure test.

Thanks.

Hi Nabeel,

I just attached the example and jmeter project which I used to invoke the service. Please check out the ENTESB-920.tgz for more information.

BTW, I run the test within JBoss Fuse 610139, the camel route can handle 400 TPS request without any error in my 2 years old MacBookPro.

Regards,

Willem

I’ve run some initial tests. I used build 139 I found the same troubles using our framework.
So, as agreed, I deployed your project to see what would happen and I did the following:

1. Deployed your flows, but disabled your stubs, and pointed the route to my HTTP Netty Stub.
Ø This showed the same issues.
2. Then, still using your flows, I stopped my stub, and enabled yours.
Ø This time it seemed it was running well, and felt could go high in TPS

So, obviously this made me think…
I have the feeling the project you passed me is using the “keep-alive”, keeping the HTTP connection open between the Camel route and the Stubs.
When I use my stubs I force the connection to be closed, this is intentional, to stress the server.

The project you passed me is basically sending to 2 possible destinations, so you actually have 2 stubs.
I checked into the Camel Netty HTTP options and I don’t see how to disable the keep-alive, and because the stubs are also using the camel netty http component, I suspect the keep-alive is helping the flow to be performant for whatever reason.
To be honest, I’m not confident this is enough to explain your stubs permit high TPS rate, but could you please pass the info to the engineers? They may investigate deeper.
Ask them please to close the connections for every call.

On my side I’ll try to get a more clear picture of the addressed above, and will come back to you if I find more revealing data.

I found the option to close the connection and I used it with your stubs.
Now what I see is Fuse throwing some exceptions and responding the client with some 500 error codes.

It’s not exactly the same behaviour as when I run against my stub but there is something not running as expected.

Hi Nabeel,

I just changed my route to close the connection by adding the option of disconnect=true just like this.

from("netty-http:http://0.0.0.0:8901/test")
 
                .process(new Processor() {
 
 
 
                    @Override
 
                    public void process(Exchange exchange) throws Exception {
 
                        int number = count.incrementAndGet();
 
                        if ((number % 2) == 1) {
 
                            exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8908/test?disconnect=true&bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                        } else {
 
                            exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8909/test?disconnect=true&bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");
 
                        }
 
 
 
                    }
 
 
 
                })
 
                .recipientList(simple("${property.target.uri}"));
 
 

I used nestat to checked the local port number is change per invocation, so the client is disconnected from server after each invocation. I ran my performance test, I cannot reproducer the error.
What I found is JVM (oracle JDK 1.7.0_45) crashed with below message. When I switch JVM to (JDK 1.6.0_65), I cannot get the error any more.

java(2543,0x139835000) malloc: *** error for object 0x139824200: pointer being freed was not allocated
 
*** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug
 
Abort trap: 6

When the Camel route is wrong (500 error is returned), there must be some stack trace in the $FUSE/data/log/fuse.log, It could be helpful for us to find the key of the issue by checking the stack trace.

Regards,

Willem

Hi Nabeel,

I just have a quick look at the log, I can reproduce the error with a lower TPS clients which don't set the keep alive option.
Back to the route issue, as the customer wants to close the connection per invocation, so we need to let the Netty know it should close the connection after receive the response, so we need to tell Netty to close the connection by using the option disconnect=true on the NettyHttpProducer side like I showed earlier today, then you can avoid getting the Exception as the log shows with lower TPS.
I ran a performance test with 400 client to send the invocation with that option, and got zero error.

exchange.setProperty("target.uri", "netty-http:http://localhost:8908/test?disconnect=true&bridgeEndpoint=true&throwExceptionOnFailure=false");

BTW, if we want to get a higher TPS, we should leverage the HTTP 1.1's keep alive to reuse the connection in the proxy producer side.

In response to your engineer’s comments, tell them we’ve tested HTTP to JMS, and JMS to HTTP scenarios, and this was never a problem.

As far as I understand the HTTP header connection just indicates the server what to do, but it’s not forcing it to do it, either side may close the connection, and that should not break any of both sides.

In response to the “keep-alive” comment, bear in mind, these are performance tests to stress the systems, we’re intentionally closing the connections. Real clients may or may not want to keep the connection alive.

At this point I’m not sure if you have info enough to keep investigating or you’re waiting anything else from us, please confirm.

Hi Nabeel,

As I had mentioned, we fixed some issues of camel-netty-http when we did the performance test after this issue and I'd like to keep polishing the camel-netty-http with the feedbacks from the customer.

camel-netty-http is new added component, I'm not sure if HTTP to JMS and JMS to HTTP scenarios used camel-netty-http component or not, and proxy could not pass the connection header across the JMS endpoint.

I made a patch for camel-netty and camel-netty-http to let producer close the connection when the connection header is not keep alive, so we can let the real clients decide if they want to close the connection or not.

Please check out the patched jars and copy it to Fuse system directory after deleting the $FUSE/data directory, and the customer doesn't need to change the route to run the test.

Regards,

Willem
Added the patched jar of camel-netty, and camel-netty-http.

Had put this comment a day back, but apparently, it didn't get submitted:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I’m having troubles deploying the Patch.
I found the bit of documentation where it is explained:
https://access.redhat.com/site/documentation/en-US/JBoss_Fuse/6.0/html/Configuring_and_Running_JBoss_Fuse/files/ESBRuntimePatchStandalone.html

When I execute the command “patch: add” as documented, the shell comes back with an empty list of patches:
[name] [installed] [description]

If I then I execute “patch:simulate” I get:
“Error executing command patch:simulate: arguments PATCH is required”.
Obviously I don’t have a Patch ID to provide.

Could you please advise?

When I delete the data/cache directory, does it means all my deployed bundles and installed features get deleted? And then I have the redeploy everything?

And what are the instructions to rollback then?

Yeah in fact you will.

Another way is to still copy the JAR and override the file in the system directory.
And then from the shell do a update xxx where xxx is the bundle id of the JAR, and do that for both of them.

And then restart the ESB. And then when restarted you can do the headers xxx to see the headers of that bundle, and make sure the build-by is from Willem. Just to be sure the OSGi container has picked up the updated JAR.
Please back the old system jar if you want to rollback with the change that Claus just showed.

Thanks for the info.

Yesterday I got brave enough to go and deploy the patch, I managed to confirm I was running the patch (I think)

It said:

  • Built-By: trustin

Is ‘trustin’ the same person as Willem?

I’ll be running the tests today.

I keep seeing the same troubles when testing the patch.

I’m trying to do some more trials to see if I can get some useful data.

Hi Nabeel,

I'm sure you just checked the header of Netty bundle which is build by Trustin Lee, not the camel-netty and camel-netty-http.
When you update those two bundle of camel, you should see my name jiangning

Built-By = jiangning

Willem

Good news!
After successfully verifying the patch was well in place, the test cases I yesterday passed to you executed without any problem.

I then shifted to test our framework for the HTTP to HTTP scenario with the patch, and that worked successfully as well, so it would seem the problem has been tackled.

I asked now the migration team to run a full performance test running with very high TPS rates to confirm it also ok on their side.
My expectation is they will succeed, but let’s wait and see, I’ll keep you updated once I get news from them.

If we get a positive, could you please indicate how should we handle this patch?
Would we get an official patch? I mean, one of those we can apply following the documentation?

And finally, could you please ask your engineer for a more in detail description of what correction the patch is including?
What exactly was the problem? And why both client and server were entering in conflict?
This is purely for me to get a better understanding.

The patch was applied into Fuse git repository, it will be a part of next Fuse release.

The problem is not conflict of netty client (producer) and server (consumer). I finally found the key of issue when we had the discussion of setting the Http Header "Connection:Close". It is that netty-http client doesn't take "Connection:Close" header into consideration. When there are large load of request, netty-http client may send the request through a closing channel ( the server may already closed the socket but the client doesn't know about it), the client just know the channel is closed by sending the message to the channel, and your client get the 500 error as the client throw channel already closed exception.

The patch just let the netty-http client close the connection aggressively when the Http header is "connection:close", you can always set the header "Connection:Keep-Alive" before routing the message to netty-http client and you can get a better performance.

from("netty-http://xxx").setHeader("Connection", "Keep-Alive").to("netty-http://yyy");
